appendix.title: Administrative Commands
appendix.para: This section lists some basic commands for performing administratice commands. It is not a complete reference for each command. For that information you should refer to the command's man page.

section.title: Daemon/Service Status
section.para: Older versions of RHEL and Fedora use the chkconfig command to display the status of a daemon/service.
Newer versions of RHEL and Fedora use the systemctl command to display the status of a daemon/service.

section.title: Starting and Stopping a Daemon/Service
section.para: Older versions of RHEL and Fedora use the chkconfig command to start and stop a daemon/service.
section.programlisting: # start a service chkconfig service on # stop a service chkconfig service off
section.para: Newer versions of RHEL and Fedora use the systemctl command to start and stop a daemon/service.
section.programlisting: systemctl start service systemctl stop service

section.title: Installing a Package

note.title: Warning
note.para: You should always use yum to install a package. Never use the rpm command. Doing so will cause problems since the RPM database will be out of sync with the YUM database.

section.para: Current versions of RHEL and Fedora use the yum command to install packages from the known repositories.

section.title: Daemon/Service Status
section.para: Older versions of Ubuntu use the chkconfig command to display the status of a daemon/service.
Newer versions of Ubuntu do not install the chkconfig command. The only way to tell if a daemon/service is running is with the ps command unless you install a replacement command.

section.title: Starting and Stopping a Daemon/Service
section.para: You should refer to the Ubuntu documentation for advice on how to start or stop a daemon/service. Future versions may use the systemctl command.
